title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
This report documents the construction of the base dataset for analyzing inequalities in Neonatal Critical Care (NCC) access in England. The dataset links maternity services data (MSDS) with critical care data to create a comprehensive birth-level dataset for hierarchical modeling.
Key findings:

Final dataset: 512,032 births in financial year 2023/24
NCC admission rate: 12.52% (64,109 babies)
Critical data quality issue identified and resolved: MSDS tables contained 2-10x duplication due to multiple submissions
Data source selection: Critical Care (CC) data preferred over MSDS for NCC admissions due to contractual reporting requirements and better data quality

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
2.1 Data Sources

2.1.1 Primary Data Sources

MSDS (Maternity Services Dataset) - NHS Digital national maternity data:

MSD401BabyDemographics_1: Birth details and baby demographics
MSD301LabourDelivery_1: Labour and delivery information
MSD101PregnancyBooking_1: Pregnancy booking and social factors
MSD001MotherDemog_1: Mother demographics
MSD402NeonatalAdmission_1: MSDS-reported neonatal admissions

Critical Care (Pbr_CC_Monthly) - Daily-level critical care records:

Filtered by CC_Type = 'NCC' for neonatal critical care
Contains care levels, length of stay, and clinical details
Used for Payment by Results (contractual requirement)

APCS (Admitted Patient Care Spells) - APCS_Core_Daily:

Provides NHS Numbers for linkage between MSDS and CC data
Essential linkage table




2.1.2 Data Linkage Strategy

Start with MSDS births (MSD401BabyDemographics_1) as base
Link MSDS tables via Labour_Delivery_ID, UniqPregID, Person_ID_Mother
Link to CC data via NHS_Number (pseudonymized) through APCS
Apply 90-day date proximity filter when linking births to CC admissions
Compare NCC admission status from both MSDS and CC sources



2.1.3 Time Period

Financial Year: 2023/24 (April 1, 2023 - March 31, 2024)
Database: UDAL_Warehouse on Azure Synapse Analytics

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
2.2 Critical Data Quality Issue: Duplication

2.2.1 Problem Identified
Initial analysis revealed massive duplication in all MSDS tables due to multiple submissions:



Table 1: Duplication Statistics in MSDS Tables


Table
Raw Records
Unique IDs
Duplication Factor
Natural Key




MSD401 (Baby Demographics)
1,838,436
541,276
3.4x
Person_ID_Baby


MSD301 (Labour/Delivery)
1,817,611
501,767
3.6x
LabourDeliveryID


MSD101 (Pregnancy/Booking)
8,080,487
798,854
10.1x
UniqPregID


MSD402 (Neonatal Admissions)
107,089
51,126
2.1x
Person_ID_Baby + Transfer Date/Time


MSD001 (Mother Demographics)
41,462,657 (all time)
4,155,888
~10x
Person_ID_Mother





Without deduplication, the final dataset would have contained ~1.8 million records instead of the expected ~540,000 births.


2.2.2 Root Cause Analysis
Investigation of duplicate records revealed:

495,826 babies (91.6%) had duplicate records in MSD401
50.3% had exactly 2 records, 17.9% had exactly 4 records
Some babies had up to 32 duplicate records

Detailed field-by-field comparison showed:

45 out of 50 fields were identical across duplicates
Only 5 submission metadata fields differed: UniqSubmissionID, AuditId, MSD401_ID, RecordNumber, CareProfLIDDel
99%+ of duplicates had identical clinical data

Conclusion: Duplicates represent multiple submissions of identical data, not different clinical events.


2.2.3 Deduplication Strategy
Applied consistent deduplication across all MSDS tables:
ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
  PARTITION BY [natural_key]
  ORDER BY UniqSubmissionID DESC  -- Most recent submission
) AS rn

-- Then filter: WHERE rn = 1
This approach: - Keeps the most recent submission for each unique entity - Preserves data integrity (clinical values are consistent) - Reduces dataset from 1.8M to 512k records (correct granularity)

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
2.3 NCC Data Source Comparison

2.3.1 Dual Source Validation
NCC admission status was captured from two sources for comparison:

MSDS: MSD402NeonatalAdmission_1 table
CC: Pbr_CC_Monthly filtered by CC_Type = 'NCC'




Table 2: NCC Admission by Data Source


Source
Number of Babies
Percentage




Both MSDS & CC
11,164
2.18


CC only
48,294
9.43


MSDS only
4,651
0.91


Not admitted to NCC
447,923
87.48







2.3.2 Source Discrepancy Analysis



Table 3: NCC Admission Rates by Data Source


Data Source
NCC Admissions
Percentage of Births
Data Quality




MSDS (MSD402)
15,815
3.09%
Low - 3.09%


CC (Pbr_CC_Monthly)
59,458
11.61%
Preferred - 11.61%


Combined (Either Source)
64,109
12.52%
Final - 12.52%





Key findings:

Only 17.4% overlap between MSDS and CC sources (11,164 of 64,109 admissions)
CC captures 3.76x more NCC admissions than MSDS (59,458 vs 15,815)
75.3% of NCC admissions are found in CC data only



2.3.3 Reasons for Discrepancy

Contractual reporting: CC data (Pbr_CC_Monthly) is required for Payment by Results, ensuring better compliance
Definition differences: MSDS MSD402 captures “transfers” to neonatal units, while CC captures all babies receiving critical care (including in-situ care)
Linking failures: NHS number linkage between MSDS and APCS may miss some babies
MSDS underreporting: Inconsistent completion of MSD402 records across trusts



2.3.4 Decision: Use CC as Primary Source
Based on this analysis, Critical Care data (CC) is used as the primary source for NCC admissions in the final dataset:

Higher capture rate (11.61% vs 3.09%)
Contractual requirement ensures data quality
More comprehensive definition of NCC care
Better aligns with clinical reality

The combined flag NCC_Admitted = 1 if baby appears in either MSDS or CC, but CC drives the majority of identifications.

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
4.2 Known Data Limitations

Birth weight and Apgar scores: Not available in MSD401BabyDemographics_1 table. Available in MSD405CareActivityBaby_1 but not yet linked.
Mother’s age: Mother’s date of birth not available in MSD001MotherDemog_1, preventing calculation of maternal age at delivery.
Deprivation (IMD): Mother’s full postcode not available. Requires separate linkage using LSOA codes.
NCC admission discrepancies: Only 17.4% overlap between MSDS and CC sources suggests ongoing data quality issues in MSDS reporting.
NHS number linkage: Some babies may not link between MSDS and CC due to pseudonymization or missing NHS numbers.

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
5.1 Database Connection

Platform: NHS UDAL (Unified Data Access Layer) on Azure Synapse Analytics
Authentication: Azure Active Directory Interactive
Access: Requires UDAL data access permissions

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
5.2 SQL Query Structure
The final query consists of several CTEs (Common Table Expressions):

ncc_from_cc: Aggregates daily CC records to baby-level
apcs_link: Provides NHS numbers for linkage
ncc_cc_with_nhs: Links CC data to NHS numbers
msds_babies_raw + msds_babies: Deduplicates baby demographics
msds_labour_raw + msds_labour: Deduplicates labour/delivery records
msds_mothers_raw + msds_mothers: Deduplicates mother demographics
msds_pregnancy_raw + msds_pregnancy: Deduplicates pregnancy/booking records
msds_neonatal_adm_raw + msds_neonatal_adm: Deduplicates neonatal admissions
base_dataset: Joins all deduplicated tables together

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
5.3 Output

Format: RDS (R Data Serialization)
Filename: data/ncc_base_dataset.rds
Records: 512,032
Fields: 59
Granularity: One record per baby born in hospital in 2023/24

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
6.1 For Hierarchical Modeling
The dataset is now ready for hierarchical (mixed-effects) modeling to examine:

Fixed effects (patient characteristics):

Baby: Sex, ethnicity, gestation, birth order
Mother: Ethnicity, social factors, employment, disability
Delivery: Method, location

Random effects (hospital/provider variation):

NCC_Hospital_Provider_Code: Where NCC care was provided
Delivery_Site_Code: Where baby was born
Org_ID_Commissioner: Commissioning organization

Outcome variables:

Binary: NCC_Admitted (1/0)
Time-to-event: Hours_Birth_To_NCC_CC (for survival/frailty models)

title: Neonatal Critical Care Base Dataset: Construction and Descriptive Statistics
text:
6.2 Additional Data Enrichment Needed

Deprivation indices: Link LSOA codes to IMD scores
Birth weight and Apgar scores: Join MSD405CareActivityBaby_1 table
Geography: Link to CCG/ICB boundaries and rural/urban classifications
Clinical severity measures: Additional neonatal clinical indicators if available
